subsections.text: Substitution of coverage (also known as crowd-out) occurs when someone with private insurance drops their private coverage and substitutes it with publicly funded insurance such as CHIP.

questions.label: Do you track the number of children who have access to private insurance?
What percent of children who enrolled in CHIP had access to private health insurance at the time of application?

conditional_display.comment: Interactive: Hide if 2020-03-b-01-01 is no, N/A, or unanswered; noninteractive: hide if that's no or N/A.

questions.label: Do you use a database to match children to their private insurance status?
Which database do you use?

conditional_display.comment: Interactive: Hide if 2020-03-b-01-02 is no, N/A, or unanswered; noninteractive: hide if that's no or N/A.

questions.label: Does your S-CHIP program require a child to be uninsured for a minimum amount of time before enrollment (“the waiting period”)?
How long is the waiting period?
Which populations does the waiting period apply to?  (Include FPLs for each group.)
What exemptions apply to the waiting period?
What percent of children subject to the waiting period meet an exemption?
What percent of children screened for S-CHIP eligibility cannot be enrolled because they have group health plan coverage?

questions.label: Anything else you’d like to add about crowd-out that wasn’t already covered? Did you run into any limitations when collecting data?

subsections.title: Substitution of Coverage (Crowd-out)

questions.label: Does your state provide presumptive eligibility, allowing children who are presumed to be eligible to access CHIP services?

Of the children who are presumptively enrolled, what percent are determined fully eligible and enrolled in the program?

conditional_display.comment: Interactive: Hide these two subquestions if the answer to 2020-03-c-01-01 is no or N/A.

questions.label: In an effort to retain more children in CHIP, do you conduct follow-up communication with families through caseworkers and outreach workers?
Do you send renewal reminder notices to families?
How many notices do you send to families before disenrolling a child from the program?
How many days before the end of the eligibility period did you send reminder notices to families?

conditional_display.comment: Interactive: Hide these two subquestions if the answer to 2020-03-c-01-03 is no or N/A.

questions.label: What else have you done to simplify the eligibility renewal process for families in order to increase retention?
Which retention strategies have you found to be most effective?
How do you measure the effectiveness of your retention strategies? What data sources and methodology do you use to track retention?
Anything else you’d like to add that wasn’t already covered?

parts.title: Eligibility Denials for First-time Applicants (Not Redetermination)

questions.hint: This only applies to denials for first-time CHIP applicants—don’t include applicants being considered for redetermination.
questions.label: How many first-time applicants were denied CHIP coverage in the last federal fiscal year?

questions.hint: For example: They were denied because of an incomplete application, missing documentation, or a missing enrollment fee.
questions.label: How many first-time applicants were denied CHIP coverage for procedural reasons?

questions.hint: For example: They were denied because their income was too high or too low, they were determined eligible for Medicaid instead, or they had other coverage available.
questions.label: How many first-time applicants were denied CHIP coverage for eligibility reasons?

questions.hint: For example: They were denied because their income was too high or too low, they were determined eligible for Medicaid instead, or they had other coverage available.
questions.label: How many first-time applicants were denied CHIP coverage for eligibility reasons?
How many applicants were denied CHIP coverage for other reasons?
Did you have any limitations in collecting this data?

parts.text: Redetermination is the process of redetermining whether a child is eligible to renew in CHIP every 12 months, assuming children haven’t already aged out of the program. Families must resubmit their income each year to determine if they still qualify for the program.
parts.title: Eligibility for Redetermination in CHIP

questions.label: How many children were eligible for redetermination in CHIP in the last federal fiscal year?
Of the eligible children, how many were then screened for redetermination?
How many children were retained in CHIP after the redetermination process?
How many children were disenrolled in CHIP after the redetermination process?
questions.comment: This is very tricky; having 4 apparently be a question the user can enter but also be the total of its subquestions presents issues. Which value takes precedence is one of them. Another is that in addition to being something that apparently can be entered by the user, it is both the output for a synthesized_value operation (sum 4a, 4b, and 4c) and the source for another synthesized_value operation (in the two tables below, where it's one of the inputs to the percentage action). My suggestion is to have 4 be a normal field of its own and have a hint next to it that sums the subquestion answers and tells the user the value they enter for 4 should equal that value. Not ideal, but otherwise we seem to have to either use custom frontend code or support way more nonsense in the data structure spec than we do already.

questions.hint: The answer to 4 should be equal to the sum of a, b, and c below:
For example: They were denied because of an incomplete application, missing documentation, or a missing enrollment fee.
questions.label: How many children were disenrolled for procedural reasons?

questions.hint: For example: They were denied because their income was too high or too low, they were determined eligible for Medicaid instead, or they had other coverage available.
questions.label: How many children were disenrolled for eligibility reasons?
How many children were disenrolled for other reasons?
Did you have any limitations in collecting this data?

questions.hint: These tables are auto-populated with the data you entered above.
questions.label: Table: Enrollment Data for CHIP Redetermination
Table: Disenrollment Data for CHIP Redetermination
questions.comment: This is assuming that we make the user manually enter the answer to question 4; otherwise we don't currently have a way to support this functionality; see the comment on question 4 above.

parts.text:
Tracking a cohort of children enrolled in CHIP (Title XXI) will measure how long a specific group stays enrolled over a 18-month period. This information is required by Section 402(a) of CHIPRA.

To track your cohort, identify a group of children ages 0 to 17 years who are newly enrolled in CHIP (Medicaid Expansion CHIP, Separate CHIP, or both) as of the first three months (Jan-Mar) of the last federal fiscal year.

Children must be 16.5 years or younger when they enroll to ensure they don’t age out of the program by the end of the 18-month tracking period.

If your eligibility system doesn’t have the ability to track a cohort, you may need to use a unique identifier or flag to track each child over the 18-month period.
parts.title: Tracking a CHIP cohort over 18 months

questions.label: January – March 2019 (start of the cohort)

questions.hint: Only include children that weren’t enrolled in CHIP the previous month. (For example: Children who enrolled in January 2020 are “newly enrolled” if they weren’t enrolled in the CHIP in December 2019.)
questions.label: How many children were newly enrolled in CHIP between January and March of the last federal fiscal year?
questions.comment: The “sum” question, that they answer if they don't have the breakdowns, can't really be a true top-level question, because then we couldn't hide it in the case where the breakdown data is available. So it has to be a subquestion, meaning that the top-level question isn't real and can't actually be answered. This introduces the need for the special fieldset used here; see the schema docs for more details.

Yes, this is a marked fieldset, i.e. a fieldset mainly pretending to be a question for the purposes of the list markers, immediately followed by an unmarked_descendants fieldset used so that the age range breakdown question gets to pretend to not be a question for the purposes of the list markers.

questions.label: I don’t have data for the individual age groups. I’ll report data for the total number for all age groups (0-18 years) instead.

subsections.text: Cost sharing is the share of costs that CHIP enrollees pay out of pocket. Cost sharing can include enrollment fees, premium fees, deductibles, coinsurance, copayments, and any other out-of-pocket costs. States can choose to require cost sharing or not.

questions.label: Does your state require cost sharing?
Who tracks cost sharing to ensure families don’t pay more than the 5% aggregate household income in a year?
What information or tools do you provide families with so they can track cost sharing?

parts.text: States with a premium assistance program can use CHIP funds to purchase coverage through employer sponsored insurance (ESI) on behalf of eligible children and parents.

subsections.text:
States can use up to 10% of their actual or estimated federal expenditures to develop Health Services Initiatives (HSI) that provide direct services and other public health initiatives for low-income children. [See Section 2105(a)(1)(D)(ii) of the Social Security Act.] States can only develop HSI programs after funding other costs to administer their CHIP State Plan, as defined in regulations at 42 CFR 457.10.
 All states with approved HSI program(s) should complete this section.

questions.label: Does your state operate Health Service Initiatives using CHIP (Title XXI) funds?

parts.text: Tell us about each of your HSI programs.

questions.label: What is the name of your HSI program?
Which populations are served by your HSI program?
How many children do you estimate are served by your HSI program?

questions.hint: Skip the following sections if you're already reporting this information elsewhere to CMS.

questions.label: How many children in the HSI program are below your state's FPL threshold?
How do you measure the HSI program’s impact on the health of low-income children in your state? Define a metric to measure the impact.
What outcomes have you found in measuring the impact?

parts.text: Indicate any changes you’ve made to your Medicaid expansion CHIP programs/policies in the past federal fiscal year. All changes require a State Plan Amendment (SPA).
parts.title: Changes in Medicaid Expansion CHIP Programs and Policies

questions.label: Have you made any changes to the eligibility determination process?
Have you made any changes to the eligibility redetermination process?

questions.hint: For example: increasing the FPL or income levels, or other eligibility criteria.
questions.label: Have you made any changes to the eligibility levels or target populations?

questions.hint: For example: adding or removing different types of coverage.
questions.label: Have you made any changes to the benefits available to enrolees?
Have you made any changes to the single streamlined application?
Have you made any changes to your outreach efforts?

questions.hint: For example: transitioning from Fee for Service to Managed Care for different CHIP populations.
questions.label: Have you made any changes to the delivery system(s)?

questions.hint: For example: changing amounts, populations, or the collection process.
questions.label: Have you made any changes to your cost sharing requirements?

questions.hint: For example: changing substitutions or the waiting periods.
questions.label: Have you made any changes to the crowd-out policies?
Have you made any changes to an enrollment freeze and/or enrollment cap?
Have you made any changes to the enrollment process for health plan selection?

context_data.bullet_text: Enrollment process for health plan selection

questions.hint: For example: changing from the Medicaid Fair Hearing Process to state law.
questions.label: Have you made any changes to the protections for applicants and enrollees?

questions.hint: For example: adding premium assistance or changing the population that receives premium assistance.
questions.label: Have you made any changes to premium assistance?
Have you made any changes to the methods and procedures for preventing, investigating, or referring fraud or abuse cases?

context_data.bullet_text: Methods and procedures for prevention, investigation, and referral of cases of fraud and abuse

questions.hint: For example: expanding eligibility to pregnant enrollees.
questions.label: Have you made any changes to your prenatal care eligibility?

questions.hint: For example: extending coverage to pregnant enrollees.
questions.label: Have you made any changes to your Pregnant Woman State Plan expansion?
Have you made any changes to eligibility for “lawfully residing pregnant women”?
Have you made any changes to eligibility for “lawfully residing children”?
Have you made any changes to any other program areas?
Anything else you'd like to add that wasn't already covered?
Do you plan to submit a SPA to reflect changes to your programs or policies if you haven’t done so already?
